New chairman of the CBS Corporation is stepping down over health related issues is just weeks after taking the position
NPR's David Folkenflik reports Richard Parsons was expected to help guide the network after scandals and controversies Richard Parsons is a former chairman at Citigroup and Time Warner named to replace CBS chairman Les Moonves after multiple women accuse Moonves of sexual harassment
CBS has hired outside lawyers to investigate those allegations and claims of inappropriate behavior by the former top executive at sixty minutes both former CBS officials have denied the allegations

A judge has blocked the New Hampshire law that would add extra steps to the registration process for first time voters as Casey McDermott of New Hampshire public radio reports the ruling comes amid concerns that the statute with dampen turnout among certain groups of voters
The law added new language to New Hampshire it's voter registration forms an stiff penalties for people who didn't present prove they lived where they were trying to vote
The state Democratic Party and the local chapter of the league of women voters filed suit to block the law last fall arguing that it was too confusing and would drive away legitimate voters they also argue that it was passed under the guise of preventing voter fraud despite a lack of evidence that such fraud in a serious problem
Finding those arguments credible a judge ordered the state to talk to the new regulations in favor of the rule to used in twenty sixteen it's unclear whether it's state attorneys plan to appeal that ruling for NPR News I'm Casey McDermott in Concord
Nearly one million people in Austin, Texas are under orders to boil their tap water from member station K. U. T. jokes of lay he reports that the directive was issued because of high concentrations of silt and the city's water supply
Austin's water utility director Greg Missouri says historic flooding in central Texas over the past week has inundated the city's water treatment plants with unprecedented concentrations of silk
The water in the river is still very very turban it looks like chocolate milk or a milk shake for example a typical drinking water is point three into use of clarity or ... river water is over four hundred we'd never seen it to that level before
He explains the city's water pressure must be kept high enough for fire protection resources and that means the tap water going out is not up to standards for consumption this morning bottled water sold out quickly at several local grocery stores as it remains unclear when the boil order will be lifted for NPR News I'm Joseph ... in Austin

A new study found the number of Americans who died from air pollution drop shortly after the clean Air Act went into effect NPR's Rebecca Hersher reports the tens of thousands of deaths were
Avoided every year after the clean Air Act was passed in Nineteen Ninety power plant and trucks and cars got cleaner and the two decades following the X. passage the amount of tiny particulate matter that we all were breathing everyday fell nearly forty percent
And according to a new study as pollution decreased lives were saved scientists found the number of pollution driven deaths each year with cut in half after the clean Air Act was passed because fewer people died of strokes respiratory illness and other conditions exacerbated are caused by pollution
But some worry that those gains may not be durable the Trump Administration has roll back regulations on some air pollutants meanwhile industry groups are suing the federal government reverse current regulations on tiny particulates in the air Rebecca Hersher NPR News

The Supreme Court says commerce secretary Wilbur Ross could not be compelled to give sworn testimony on his decision to add a citizenship question to the twenty twenty cents as

The Trump Administration is changing Affordable Care act rules to make it easier for healthy middle income Americans define less costly health insurance
As NPR's Alison Kodjak reports the new guidance also allow states to subsidize low quality plans that do not cover pre existing conditions
The new guidance said the administration may allow states to opt out of traditional Affordable Care act markets states instead could encourage insurance companies to offer health plans with fewer benefits at lower prices and for the first time people who buy those policies may be able to use government subsidies to pay for them
Under the SEA insurance policies have to include a standard set of benefits available to anyone at a single price
The administration says it wants to offer more choices to consumers and to allow people who don't qualify for government help to be able to find insurance that they can afford Alison Kodjak NPR News Washington
